item.title: Software
item.description: To develop games using Pygame Zero, you have two main options: use Mu use another editor Mu is set up to be very helpful for beginners. It has some keyboard shortcuts, good help text, nice shortcut buttons, and is generaly very friendly to use and has a lot of features to help beginners get started. After you have been writing code for a while, you may find that a standard Python environment and a “full” text editor like Visual Studio Code allows you a lot more power and flexibility, at the cost of doing some more basic things yourself.

item.title: Structuring your files
item.description: Each of your projects should live in its own folder somewhere sensible (like in a Digital Tech folder in your OneDrive!). project/ ├── game.py │ ├── images/ │ ├── someImage.jpg │ ├── anotherImage.jpg │ └── ... # sprites, tiles and other image files │ ├── fonts/ │ └── ... # any font files │ ├── sounds/ │ └── ... # any sound files │ └── music/ └── ... # any music files You don’t need to have those folders unless you have something to put in them.
